docs.lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn hospital has sued one of the city’s largest health insurers, asserting it conspired with doctors to wrongfully deny coverage for patients.
docs.snippet: A Brooklyn hospital has sued one of the city’s largest health insurers, asserting it conspired with doctors to wrongfully deny coverage for patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn hospital has sued one of the city's largest health insurers, asserting it conspired with doctors and others to wrongfully deny coverage for patients. The suit, filed by Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, says the financially distressed hospital was forced to absorb a significant portion of costs that should have been paid by Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, a managed care organization commonly known as HIP.
docs.abstract: Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center sues Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, one of New York City's largest health insurers, saying it was forced to absorb significant portion of costs that should have been paid by insurer; HIP officials deny allegations; suit focuses on process used by insurer to determine what procedures are medically necessary (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After weeks of internal squabbling, state workers approved a four-year contract on Thursday that will give them a 13 percent overall pay increase but will also require that they pay part of their health insurance premiums for the first time. The new contract affects about 43,000 state workers affiliated with the Communications Workers of America and will take effect on July 1. Workers will contribute an extra half of 1 percent of their salary to the state’s troubled pension fund, and the retirement age for new employees will be raised to 60 from 55. The contract ratification is a political victory for Gov. Jon S. Corzine, who has been outspoken about his desire to control spiraling pension and health care costs.
